Definitions

All of the definitions that go into defining this service, from the original schema, the OpenAPI definitions, the Postman Collections, and the assertions that contribute to the testing of the service to ensure it is doing what is expected of it.


Definition → Organization

The over-arching source control organization for this service, providing an umbrella for different development groups and projects.


Services:

  • → GitHub - GitHub Inc. is a web-based hosting service for version control using Git, used for distributed version control and source code management functionality of Git.
  • → GitLab - GitLab is a web-based Git-repository manager with wiki, issue-tracking and CI/CD pipeline features.
  • → Bitbucket - Bitbucket is a web-based version control repository hosting service for source code and development projects that use either Mercurial or Git revision control systems.

Links:

  • →

Definition → Repository

The source control repository for this service, providing a self-contained, shareable, forkable way to engage with a service. Allowing for EVERYTHING involved with a service to be accessed in a single location.


Services:

  • → GitHub - GitHub Inc. is a web-based hosting service for version control using Git, used for distributed version control and source code management functionality of Git.
  • → GitLab - GitLab is a web-based Git-repository manager with wiki, issue-tracking and CI/CD pipeline features.
  • → Bitbucket - Bitbucket is a web-based version control repository hosting service for source code and development projects that use either Mercurial or Git revision control systems.

Links:

  • →

Definition → README

The README for this services repository, providing an overview of the service, complete with all the relevant links to all the moving parts. Any user should be able to land on the README, and easily get up to speed on what a service delivers.


Services:

  • → GitHub - GitHub Inc. is a web-based hosting service for version control using Git, used for distributed version control and source code management functionality of Git.
  • → GitLab - GitLab is a web-based Git-repository manager with wiki, issue-tracking and CI/CD pipeline features.
  • → Bitbucket - Bitbucket is a web-based version control repository hosting service for source code and development projects that use either Mercurial or Git revision control systems.

Definition → Service Name

A simple title for this service, describing what it does in concise terms, providing a simple way for any internal or external part to learn about the value it offers.


Definition → Service Description

A simple, descriptive paragraph for this service.


Definition → Service Goals

Providing some basic goals for this service.


Definition → Schema

JSON schema for the data behind service.


Tools:

  • → JSON Schema - JSON Schema is a vocabulary that allows you to annotate and validate JSON documents.

Definition → OpenAPI

An OpenAPI definition for the surface area of the API.


Tools:

  • → OpenAPI - The OpenAPI specification for describing the surface area of the API.

Definition → Domain

Considering the domain that this service fits into.


Definition → Tags

Defining what the tagging taxonomy will be for applying across resources, for use in tagging across definitions, documentation, and infrastructure operations.


Definition → Assertions

Human and machine readable assertions of what service does.


Definition → Team

A list of team members for the service.


Design


Design → Versioning

Managing the version for the various layers of this service.


Design → Base Path

The part of the path that goes after the host, and before each path, and is constant across all endpoints for this service.


Design → Path(s)

The paths that are used to define each individual API resource.


Design → Verb(s)

The HTTP verbs used for this service, including GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE.


Links:

  • →

Design → Parameters

The query parameters that are used by this service, as described by the OpenAPI.


Design → Headers

The headers that are used by this service, as described by the OpenAPI.


Links:

  • →

Design → Body

Usage of the body as part of API requests as opposed to parameters, or in parallel to.


Design → Beyond Verbs

Consistently defining how actions will be designed beyond the usage of the common HTTP verbs.


Design → Media Types

The media types that are used by this service, as described by the OpenAPI.


Tools:

  • → IANA Media Types - Media types that are defined by IANA.

Design → Status Codes

The HTTP status codes that are used by this service, as described by the OpenAPI.


Tools:

  • → Wikipedia List of HTTP status codes - A list of all HTTP status codes for reference.

Design → Filtering

Allowing for the filtering of data returned as part of responses.


Design → Pagination

The pagination used by this service, as described by the OpenAPI.


Design → Sorting

The sorting used by this service, as described by the OpenAPI.


Design → Response(s)

The responses that are used by this service, as described by the OpenAPI.


Design → Errors

Defining a structure for error handling that leverages HTTP status codes, but goes further with a common schema definition.

Issues

Being transparent around the issues that are currently outstanding regarding a platform. Potentially saving resources having to respond to further emails, tickets, and issues being reported.

Change Log

Provide consumers with a detail history of what has changed in the past with a service. Rolling over road map items, and issues when they have been accomplished or satisfied into a detailed change log.


Change Log → Entries

Providing a list of what has changed with this platform along with each road map item being accomplished, and issue being resolved.
